function_names.name: Power
function_names.detailed_description:
These are the CM4's power input and output pins:
  • 6 x 5V input pins
  • 2 x 1.8V Output pins
  • 2 x 3.3V Output pins
  • GPIO_VREF, which controls whether the GPIO pins operate at 3v3 or 1v8

function_names.name: System
function_names.detailed_description:
These are pins for controlling and monitoring the Raspberry Pi system.
  • Wifi and Bluetooth disable pins
  • Power and actvity output LEDs
  • Reset and shutdown pins
  • Fan control

function_names.name: PIO
function_names.detailed_description:
Originally included on the RP2040, the Programmable IO interface provides a series of hardware state machines, programmable using a domain-specific assembly language.  This effectively allows one to create custom software-defined hardware peripherals, freeing up the CPU for other tasks.
At the time of writing there isn't much documentation on how to use this peripheral with the CM5

function_names.name: RIO
function_names.detailed_description: An interface which allows the host processor to manipulate GPIOs directly. This is a feature of the RP1 coprocessor. There's isn't that much documentation on it at the time of writing, so check the RP1 Peripherals Documentation for more info.

function_names.name: GPIO
function_names.detailed_description: Pins that can be used as digital inputs or outputs as needed. See the Raspberry Pi documentation

function_names.name: GPCLK
function_names.detailed_description: Can be configured to output a fixed frequency on a pin. There's not much documentation on this, but pinout.xyz has an introduction

function_names.name: I2S
function_names.detailed_description: PCM-based interface for moving high quality multi-channel digital audio

function_names.name: SPI
function_names.detailed_description: SPI Controller. The CM4 has 7 SPI controllers, details are on the Raspberry Pi documentation

function_names.name: UART
function_names.detailed_description: UART1 - UART4 support the regular 4-wire interface (TX, RX, CTS, RTS), where UART0 supports either an 8-wire interface (TX, RX, CTS, RTS, DTR, DCD, DSR, RI), or an IrDA interface (IR_TX, IR_RX).

function_names.name: Audio Out
function_names.detailed_description: PWM Audio which requires buffering using a low noise PSU noise buffer and filtering with a 22 kHz 1st order RC network

function_names.name: SDIO
function_names.detailed_description: Used to connect the CM5 Lite to an SD Card.  If not using a CM5 Lite, this is used for the onboard eMMC, and shouldn't be used.

function_names.name: PCIe
function_names.detailed_description: PCIe Gen2 x 1 controller.  May be operated as a Gen3.0 controller but this mode is unsupported

function_names.name: Ethernet
function_names.detailed_description: On-board 1G Ethernet using the BCM54210 PHY, which provides IEEE 1588-2008 features, MDI crossover, and pair skew and polarity correction. Designed to be wired directly to a 1:1 RJ45 MagJack connector.

function_names.name: USB 2.0
function_names.description: Universal Serial Bus, version 2.0. P/N pairs within TX or RX signals may not be swapped

function_names.name: USB 3.0
function_names.description: Universal Serial Bus, version 3.0.  P/N pairs within TX or RX signals may be swapped (but not the USB2 signal)

function_names.name: DPI
function_names.detailed_description: Parallel interface for controlling LCD displays. See the Raspberry Pi documentation

function_names.name: DSI
function_names.detailed_description: Serial interface for controlling LCD displays (like the official Touch display).

function_names.name: MIPI
function_names.description: Dual-mode interface for either CSI or DSI
function_names.detailed_description: This interface can either act as DSI (for displays) or CSI (for cameras).  This replaces the single-mode interfaces from the CM4.

pins.name: Ethernet_Pair3_P
pins.description: Ethernet Pair 3 Positive (connect to transformer or MagJack)

pins.name: Ethernet_Pair1_P
pins.description: Ethernet Pair 1 Positive (connect to transformer or MagJack)

pins.name: Ethernet_Pair3_N
pins.description: Ethernet Pair 3 Negative (connect to transformer or MagJack)

pins.name: Ethernet_Pair1_N
pins.description: Ethernet Pair 1 Negative (connect to transformer or MagJack)

pins.name: Ethernet_Pair2_N
pins.description: Ethernet Pair 2 Negative (connect to transformer or MagJack)

pins.name: Ethernet_Pair0_N
pins.description: Ethernet Pair 0 Negative (connect to transformer or MagJack)

pins.name: Ethernet_Pair2_P
pins.description: Ethernet Pair 2 Positive (connect to transformer or MagJack)

pins.name: Ethernet_Pair0_P
pins.description: Ethernet Pair 0 Positive (connect to transformer or MagJack)

pins.name: Ethernet_nLED3
pins.description: Active-Low Ethernet Activity indicator (3.3V signal) Typically a Green LED is connected to this pin: IOL = 8mA @ VOL< 0.4V

pins.name: Fan_Tacho
pins.description: Fan Tacho Input pin internally pulled up with a 1.8K resistor to CM5_3.3V

pins.name: Ethernet_nLED2
pins.description: Active-low Ethernet speed indicator (CM5_3.3V signal): typically a yellow LED is connected to this pin. A low state indicates the 1Gbit or 100Mbit link: IOL = 8mA @ VOL < 0.4V

pins.name: Ethernet_SYNC_OUT
pins.description: IEEE1588 SYNC Output pin ( 1.8V signal : IOL = 8mA @ VOL< 0.4V )

pins.name: EEPROM_nWP
pins.description: Leaving floating NB internally pulled up to CM5_3.3V via 100K ( VIL <0.8V) but can be grounded to prevent writing to the on board EEPROM which stores the bootcode

pins.name: LED_nACT
pins.description: Active-Low Pi Activity LED. 20mA Max 5V tolerant ( VOL<0.4V). ( this is the signal that drives the Green LED on the Raspberry Pi 5 )

pins.name: GPIO26
pins.description: GPIO: typically a 3.3V signal, but can be a 1.8V signal by connecting GPIO_VREF to CM5_1.8V

pins.name: GPIO21
pins.description: GPIO: typically a 3.3V signal, but can be a 1.8V signal by connecting GPIO_VREF to CM5_1.8V

pins.description: GPIO: typically a 3.3V signal, but can be a 1.8V signal by connecting GPIO_VREF to CM5_1.8V

pins.description: GPIO: typically a 3.3V signal, but can be a 1.8V signal by connecting GPIO_VREF to CM5_1.8V

pins.description: GPIO: typically a 3.3V signal, but can be a 1.8V signal by connecting GPIO_VREF to CM5_1.8V

pins.name: GPIO6
pins.description: GPIO Typically a 3.3V signal but can be a 1.8V signal by connecting GPIO_Vref to 1.8V.  Internal pull-up

pins.name: GPIO12
pins.description: GPIO: typically a 3.3V signal, but can be a 1.8V signal by connecting GPIO_VREF to CM5_1.8V

pins.name: GPIO5
pins.description: GPIO Typically a 3.3V signal but can be a 1.8V signal by connecting GPIO_Vref to 1.8V.  Internal pull-up

pins.name: ID_SC
pins.description:
(BCM2712 GPIO 1) GPIO: typically a 3.3V signal, but can be a 1.8V signal by connecting GPIO_VREF to CM5_1.8V
This I2C bus is normally used for identifying HATs and controlling CSI0 and DSI0 devices. If the firmware isn't using the I2C bus e.g. MIPI1 isn't being used then these pins may be used as GPIO 0 and GPIO 1 if required.
If these pins are used as GPIO pins, then to prevent the firmware from checking to see if there is a HAT EEPROM available, add force_eeprom_read=0 and disable_poe_fan=1 to the config.txt file

functions.name: GPIO1
functions.description: GPIO: typically a 3.3V signal, but can be a 1.8V signal by connecting GPIO_VREF to CM5_1.8V

pins.name: ID_SD
pins.description:
(BCM2712 GPIO 0) GPIO: typically a 3.3V signal, but can be a 1.8V signal by connecting GPIO_VREF to CM5_1.8V
This I2C bus is normally used for identifying HATs and controlling CSI0 and DSI0 devices. If the firmware isn't using the I2C bus e.g. MIPI1 isn't being used then these pins may be used as GPIO 0 and GPIO 1 if required.
If these pins are used as GPIO pins, then to prevent the firmware from checking to see if there is a HAT EEPROM available, add force_eeprom_read=0 and disable_poe_fan=1 to the config.txt file

pins.name: SD_CLK
pins.description: SD card Clock signal (only available on CM5Lite)

pins.name: GPIO2
pins.description: GPIO Typically a 3.3V signal but can be a 1.8V signal by connecting GPIO_Vref to 1.8V.  Internal pull-up

pins.name: SD_DAT3
pins.description: SD card / eMMC Data3 signal (only available on CM5Lite)

pins.name: SD_CMD
pins.description: SD card / eMMC Command signal (only available on CM5Lite)

pins.name: SD_DAT0
pins.description: SD card / eMMC Data0 signal (only available on CM5Lite)

pins.name: SD_DAT5
pins.description: SD card / eMMC Data5 signal (only available on CM5Lite)

pins.name: SD_DAT1
pins.description: SD card / eMMC Data1 signal (only available on CM5Lite)

pins.name: SD_DAT4
pins.description: SD card / eMMC Data4 signal (only available on CM5Lite)

pins.name: SD_DAT2
pins.description: SD card / eMMC Data2 signal (only available on CM5Lite)

pins.name: SD_DAT7
pins.description: SD card / eMMC Data7 signal (only available on CM5Lite)

pins.name: SD_DAT6
pins.description: SD card / eMMC Data6 signal (only available on CM5Lite)

pins.name: SD_VDD_Override
pins.description: Connect to CM5_3.3V to force SD card/eMMC interface to 1.8V signalling instead of 3.3V, otherwise leave unconnected. Typically only used if external eMMC is connected.

pins.name: SD_PWR_ON
pins.description: Output to power switch for the SD card. The CM5 sets this pin high (3.3V) to signal that power to the SD card should be turned on. Internally Pulled up to CM5_3.3v with a 4.53K (only available on CM5Lite)

pins.name: GPIO_VREF
pins.description: Must be connected to CM5_3.3V (pins 84 and 86) for 3.3V GPIO0-27 or CM5_1.8V (pins 88 and 90) for 1.8V GPIO0-27. This pin cannot be floating or connected to ground.

pins.name: SCL0
pins.description: I2C clock pin (GPIO39): typically used for Camera and Display. Internal 1.8kΩ pull-up to CM5_3.3V

pins.name: SDA0
pins.description: I2C Data pin (GPIO38): typically used for Camera and Display. Internal 1.8kΩ pull-up to CM5_3.3V

pins.name: CM5_3.3V (Output)
pins.description: 3.3V ± 5%. Power Output max 300mA per pin for a total of 600mA. This will be powered down during power-off or GLOBAL_EN being set low

pins.name: CM5_3.3V (Output)
pins.description: 3.3V ± 5%. Power Output max 300mA per pin for a total of 600mA. This will be powered down during power-off or GLOBAL_EN being set low

pins.name: CM5_1.8V (Output)
pins.description: 1.8V ± 5%. Power Output max 300mA per pin for a total of 600mA. This will be powered down during power-off or GLOBAL_EN being set low

pins.name: WL_nDisable
pins.description: Can be left floating.  If driven low the wireless interface will be disabled. Internal pulled up via 1.8K to CM5_3.3V

pins.name: CM5_1.8V (Output)
pins.description: 1.8V ± 5%. Power Output max 300mA per pin for a total of 600mA. This will be powered down during power-off or GLOBAL_EN being set low

pins.name: BT_nDisable
pins.description: Can be left floating.  If driven low the Bluetooth interface will be disabled. Internal pulled up via 1.8K to CM5_3.3V

pins.name: PWR_Button
pins.description: Pull low to force power off or power on from previous software powered off state. Internally pulled up to +5V via 10kΩ

pins.name: nRPIBOOT
pins.description: A low on this pin forces booting from an RPI server (e.g. PC or a Raspberry Pi)  if not used leave floating. Internally pulled up via 10K to CM5_3.3V

pins.name: CC1
pins.description: USB PSU PD signal , wire to a USB-C connector to enable 5A @ 5V negotiation.

pins.name: LED_nPWR
pins.description: (3.3V signal) Active-low output to drive Power On LED. This signal needs to be buffered.

pins.name: CC2
pins.description: USB PSU PD signal , wire to a USB-C connector to enable 5A @ 5V negotiation.

pins.name: CAM_GPIO0
pins.description: (3.3V signal) Can be a GPIO (GPIO34) or part of the bus with pin 100

pins.name: PMIC_Enable
pins.description: Input. Drive low to power off CM5. Internally pulled up with a 100kΩ to +5V

pins.name: CAM_GPIO1
pins.description: (3.3V signal) (GPIO35) Internally pulled up with 15K to CM5_3.3V

pins.name: USB_OTG_ID
pins.description: Input (3.3V signal) USB OTG Pin. Internally pulled up. When grounded the CM5 becomes a USB host but the correct OS driver also needs to be used

pins.name: PCIe_CLK_nREQ
pins.description: Input (3.3V signal) PCIe Clock request pin (low to request PCI clock).  Internal pulled up

pins.name: PCIE_nWAKE
pins.description: (3.3V signal) PCIe WAKE# signal can be left unconnected if wake up isn’t required, internally pulled up.

pins.name: PCIE_PWR_EN
pins.description: (3.3V signal) Active high, used to signal that a PCIe device can be powered down when low.

pins.name: VBUS_EN
pins.description: (3.3V signal) Active-high output to signal USB3 ports should be powered

pins.name: PCIe_RX_P
pins.description: Input PCIe GEN 2 RX Positive NB External AC coupling Capacitor required

pins.name: PCIe_RX_N
pins.description: Input PCIe GEN 2 RX Negative NB External AC coupling Capacitor required

pins.name: PCIe_TX_P
pins.description: Output PCIe GEN 2 TX Positive NB AC coupling Capacitor Included on CM5

pins.name: PCIe_TX_N
pins.description: Output PCIe GEN 2 TX Negative NB AC coupling Capacitor Included on CM5

pins.name: USB3-0-TX_N
pins.description: USB3 Port 0 TX output negative NB AC coupling capacitor included on CM5c

pins.name: USB3-0-TX_P
pins.description: USB3 Port 0 TX output positive NB AC coupling capacitor included on CM5

pins.name: HDMI1_HOTPLUG
pins.description: Input HDMI1 Hotplug Internally pulled down with a 100K. 5V tolerant. (It can be connected directly to a HDMI connector)

pins.name: HDMI1_SDA
pins.description: Bidirectional HDMI1 SDA Internally pulled up with a 1.8K. 5V tolerant. (It can be connected directly to a HDMI connector)

pins.name: HDMI1_SCL
pins.description: Bidirectional HDMI1 SCL Internally pulled up with a 1.8K. 5V tolerant. (It can be connected directly to a HDMI connector)

pins.name: HDMI1_CEC
pins.description: Input HDMI1 CEC Internally pulled up with a 27K. 5V tolerant. (It can be connected directly to a HDMI connector)

pins.name: HDMI0_CEC
pins.description: Input HDMI0 CEC Internally pulled up with a 27K. 5V tolerant. (It can be connected directly to a HDMI connector)

pins.name: HDMI0_HOTPLUG
pins.description: Input HDMI0 Hotplug Internally pulled down with a 100K. 5V tolerant. (It can be connected directly to a HDMI connector)

pins.name: USB3-1-TX_N
pins.description: USB3 Port 1 TX output negative NB AC coupling capacitor included on CM5

pins.name: USB3-1-TX_P
pins.description: USB3 Port 1 TX output positive NB AC coupling capacitor included on CM5

pins.name: HDMI0_SDA
pins.description: Bidirectional HDMI0 SDA Internally pulled up with a 1.8K. 5V tolerant. (It can be connected directly to a HDMI connector a small amount of ESD protection is provided on the CM5 by an on board HDMI05-CL02F3)

pins.name: HDMI0_SCL
pins.description: Bidirectional HDMI0 SCL Internally pulled up with a 1.8K. 5V tolerant. (It can be connected directly to a HDMI connector a small amount of ESD protection is provided on the CM5 by an on board HDMI05-CL02F3)
